title: Are there more doctors in the NHS than in 2010?
subtitle: There are 11,700 more doctors working in NHS hospitals and community health services in England in May 2017 compared to May 2010.
author: fullfact.org
vclaim:
Are there more doctors in the NHS than in 2010?

This is pretty much correct.

There are 11,700 more doctors working in NHS hospitals and community health services in England in May 2017 compared to May 2010 when the Conservatives originally came into office. That’s a 12% increase.

Using figures for April 2017 (which are the ones used by the Conservative party to make the claim) and comparing back to May 2010 there were 11,800 more doctors. These figures look at full time equivalent staff – that’s the number of staff there would be if you added their hours together to create only full time positions.

These don’t include the number of GPs working in England though. Information on GP numbers isn’t comparable as far back as 2010 because of changes in the way the figures were collected.

Of course this doesn’t really tell us anything about the impact this increased number of doctors has on patients and the NHS. We’ve looked at other areas including the level of satisfaction with the NHS, the number of people attending Accident and Emergency and the state of the NHS elsewhere.
